p: Temperatures in southern South America are projected to increase at least 2 °C and precipitation decrease by 10–20% as an outcome of climate change by 2100 ( Beaumont et al., 2011). These changes are predicted to lead to distribution shifts and possible extinctions of organisms dwelling in temperate forest and mountain ( Bambach et al., 2013). Under this scenario, it is critical to estimate which areas would be suitable for species conservation, and for identifying climatic variables that will determine potential areas where they could survive ( Olson & Dinerstein, 2002; Marchese, 2015).
